content: Added "write answer" to stub generator.

There's a discrepancy between the puzzle I/O that uses 0-indexing for the points whereas the example in the statement text starts at 1.

The case where the starting point already touches two points is covered in the constraints indeed, but IMHO the puzzle would be better off with that case just *not happening*.
The puzzle is hairy enough not to constrain the implementation that much more!

"Test 10" should probably be named "Infinite Loop" (whatever that means)

The output format is on par with the puzzle difficulty, but IMHO unwarranted. Better just output index of final pivot first, then tallies.

I think a lot of coders will stop reading after the first sentence, terrified by the fact, that you are talking about some math exercise for the best students of the world. And even more will drop of somewhere in the middle of the of the IMO exercise. But they'll miss a nice and doable puzzle. Maybe you can make it less intimidating by mentioning in the first paragraph, that the puzzle is inspired by the IMO but is far from solving the original problem.

Some more wording stuff: 
Definition of S: Points cannot be integer only each of their coordinates can
Constraint for N: I haven't seen 1e12 on codinggame yet, I think 10^12 is the more common way to write it.

Interesting! Edited to fix a few typos, wording and formatting problems.
When you say "The *first* rotation is Clockwise" (Constraints), is that a remainder of the issue mentioned below by bbb000bbbyyy?

Why does the rotation's direction change with each new pivot in your example ?
Looking at the IMO 2011, the rotation is always clockwise. Is it just to spice things up ?
Typo: exercice -> exercise
It's edited, thanks !

Oh god, I got confused when I read the sentence in the video : The line rotates clockwise about the pivot P until the first time that the line meets some other points of S. This point Q, takes over as the new pivot and the line now rotates clockwise about Q ...

BTW, I was also surpised to find a lot starting pivots where it is directly a loop but didn't realized this points 

I'll have to edit the exercice but also the solution (which should be easier btw) :(.

I'll set as as WIP for now
Thanks for the feedback. Nice catch, it's my mistake. It comes from the issue mentionned by bbb000bbbyyy when the rotation changed after each pivot change. It's removed :)

Thanks for your feedback. wordings are adjusted.

For the Goal, I got the same feeling when I submitted it mainly due to the last sentence of IMO "Show that for a suitable P ∈ S and a suitable starting line ℓ containing P , the resulting windmill will visit each point of S as a pivot infinitely often". 
In one hand, I wanted to remove it. But in the other hand, I wanted to keep it exactly as it has been proposed. I like the wording "inspired" so I changed the first sentence and a bit the objectives. I hope it won't scare people  anymore

Thanks for your feedback. I changed the index in the Presentation and mentionned that it is 0-indexed.

The rectangle case is modified to parallelogram to not be aligned at start (I also modified the I/O to inform that it will never intersect a point at the beginning)

I didn't saw that 1 puzzle was not named (it remains empty on the draft). It's edited :).

For the last point, I'm a bit sceptical. Having 1 output per point makes more sense than having the first output being the pivot and then one value per point (as you want, I can easily edit it)

About 0-indexing: I'm not sure I was clear. I meant the numbering of the points in the example, mostly. Currently line "The starting point is 2 so the line starts horizontally at 400, 300" reads weird since 0-indexed point 2 is (400,100). I suggest you put an explicit index next to them.

Last point is not a blocker, it's just that from an information theoretical point of view, (int,int^n) seems more simple than (int,bool)^n. To me at least (consider the cyclomatic complexity of how to output it both ways). Have it any way you like, it's really not important enough to retain approval.

Hum, I'm surprised but it seems that the update is not saved. I edited it again.

I got your point about the output. As I am mainly coding in python, I have less concern about mixing types. Anyway, it's updated

I've edited a bit more to add a mention to variable K in the example.

And I'm approving.

I *will* concede your output format was more human-readable. Just (slightly) more of a programming pain. Like, my code is about 60 characters shorter now.

Edit: re-edited to settle on "P" for the starting pivot index in statement, I/O section and stub.

Thanks for your contribution and approval :)
Whach language did you use ?
I'm in Haskell.

Youtube just independently enticed me to watch that 3b1b video, so I'll comment now.

I wholeheartedly agree with Kathrin on this one, the IMO stuff makes this more scary than need be. I'd generally downvote and/or reject a puzzle that requires an external video to solve, but I had to actually watch it to notice it isn't the case here, and that's a shame.

So please, make your puzzle standalone, don't describe it primarily as a variation from something else.

I suggest you removed the "IMO 2011" section from the top of your statement entirely, and *only* describe the windmill process as it applies to your puzzle. The only IMO reference you need keep is "This puzzle is a constructive implementation of the windmill process described in International Mathematical Olympiad 2011 problem B. Whereas the IMO problem asked the contestant to choose a pivot and prove the process's extensiveness, here you are given the starting point and only need describe the flow."

There's no need for the no-3-point-collinearity until the constraints section.

I'm a bit "sad" to remove the history of this process but that's true that the exercise is a variation of this problem.

For the collinearity, I'd prefer to keep it as you will have an issue in case 3 points are aligned. You will have 2 possible pivots. This would require an additionnal rule like (take the farthest for example) and a test case for this.
I'm not saying to remove it. I'm saying to keep it for the end (the constraints section). Most people will never notice they need it anyway.

Oh ok, I'll add some info at the end. 
If you think it could makes sense, I could draft a "part 2" where the player has to answer which point can be the pivot. That means simulate the process for each point and check if its cycle is containing each points (meaning that they will be pivot an infinite amount of time). However, it's maybe too close to this version (or check how many points are on both sides of the line).
The "Rectangle" test and validator start with an horizontal line that goes through 2 points. You should either avoid that or specify what to do in that case (immediately change pivot or not).
Contrains has been included. I wanted to keep it as a test but bbb000bbbyyy raised also this flag so it's included
Oh, ok, I did not pay enough attention to some of the previous comments that were already about that. But anyway it's certainly better to have clarified that.
Don't worry that's fine :) Thanks for the approval !
It's updated (including solution & test cases). BTW, a new test case has been created for convex hull cases
Nice but there is a problem with the 2nd test/validator. Manual simulation on the rectangle gives me the expected 3, 3, 3, 2 but the last pivot is the 2nd point instead of the 3rd.

Yes, you start at the pivot 0 and directly you intersect the point 1 so there is a change to point=1. Then the standard rotation occurs. I was thinking to turn slightly the rectangle to avoid this alignment but I think it still makes sense to have this special case ? This is the same for the validator btw but the rotation is inside the rectangle instead of outside. I can provide plots if it makes things clearer (just let me know)
Now with your explanation it makes sense. But I don't think this special case is really clear with the current statement. I guess the gamers could figure it out with the second test.
